</template>

<template>
    <lightning-card title="Case Comment" icon-name="utility:answer">
        <lightning-record-edit-form  object-api-name="Case_Comment__c" data-id="caseCommentForm">
            <lightning-input-field field-name="Comment__c" required onchange={handleCommentChange}></lightning-input-field>
            <lightning-input-field field-name="Category__c" required onchange={handleCategoryChange}></lightning-input-field>
            <lightning-input-field field-name="Visibility__c" required onchange={handleVisibilityChange}></lightning-input-field>
        </lightning-record-edit-form>
        <lightning-button
            label="Add Comment"
            variant="brand"
            disabled={disableButton}
            onclick={handleAddComment}
            >
        </lightning-button>


        
    </lightning-card>
</template>

<template>
    <c-case-comment-form 
        case-id={recordId}
        onnewcasecomment={handleNewCaseComment}
        >
    </c-case-comment-form>
    <lightning-datatable
        key-field="Id"
        data={caseComments}
        columns={columns}
        hide-checkbox-column
        >
    </lightning-datatable>
</template>

comments.comment:
That works in this case, well done! One of the reasons to use inputs over the record form is to be able to capture the changes on the fly and to avoid using this.template.querySelectorAll.

Because in some cases, with this template.querySelectorAll, you might run into trouble. For example, if you have a log of inputs that are unrelated to the inputs you are trying to develop the functionality for. You have example how I did with input change event in the skool.
https://www.loom.com/share/89ea8b9312ca4295973e209f10d4deee?sid=9dfa4763-27ba-4314-8d86-def7a5562fac
I'll approve this one, but please make sure you don't use regex next tome!
You can do it easier: "if(mixed[i])" would be enough :)
The idea was to separate "then" and promise declaration. But it's fine!
No async/await needed. We use promises for that :)

Ongoing Support Maintain live Salesforce environments and resolve any issues Varies Businesses who lack internal resources to enhance and support their live Salesforce environment

comments.comment: Add whitespeaces "}else{" -> "} else {"
I like this one. No need to account for decimals! Well done! :)
Don't forget to declare variable "i"

The solution is wrong. You're iterating through every second element and checking if the values are truthy between them. And the end result is a boolean, but it should be the value itself.

Check out the result for this: let mixed = [false, false, false, true, "", 0, "hello", undefined];
Don't forget to put "let" before any variable
No AI is allowed in the course.
If you want to use indexes, you can't really use for-each syntax. You can only use it if you want to iterate through the whole array. So I don't see a way to use for-each in this case :)

Don't forget to put a value into variables, even it's empty
all good!
Don't use arrays, just immediately print them out.
Yes, this would solve the task. But don't use it in real-world, it'd be confusing.

<template>
    <lightning-card title="Contact List" icon-name="standard:contact">
        <lightning-datatable 
            key-field="Id"
            data={contacts}
            columns={columns}
            draft-values={draftValues}
            onsave={handleSave}
            oncancel={handleCancel}
            onrowaction={handleRowAction}
            hide-checkbox-column>
        </lightning-datatable>
    </lightning-card>
</template>

<template>
    <lightning-card title="Contact List" icon-name="standard:contact">
        <lightning-button 
            label="Add Contact"
            icon-name="utility:add" 
            variant="brand" 
            onclick={addContact} 
            class="slds-m-around_x-small" 
            slot="actions">
        </lightning-button>
        <lightning-datatable 
            key-field="Id"
            data={contacts}
            columns={columns}
            draft-values={draftValues}
            onsave={handleSave}
            oncancel={handleCancel}
            hide-checkbox-column>
        </lightning-datatable>
    </lightning-card>
</template>

<template>
    <lightning-card title="Contact List" icon-name="standard:contact">
        <lightning-datatable 
            key-field="Id"
            data={contacts}
            columns={columns}
            draft-values={draftValues}
            onsave={handleSave}
            oncancel={handleCancel}
            onrowaction={handleRowAction}
            hide-checkbox-column>
        </lightning-datatable>
    </lightning-card>
</template>

<template>
     <lightning-card title="Expense Tracker" icon-name="utility:money">
        <c-expense-tracker-child
            onnewexpense={handleNewExpense}
        ></c-expense-tracker-child>
        <lightning-datatable
            key-field="Id"
            data={expenses}
            columns={columns}
            draft-values={draftValues}
            onrowaction={handleRowAction}
            hide-checkbox-column
        ></lightning-datatable>

    </lightning-card>
</template>

function deepEqual(a,b){
  return JSON.stringify(a) === JSON.stringify(b);
}


console.log(deepEqual(1, 1));                         // true 
console.log(deepEqual(1, '1'));                       // false 
console.log(deepEqual(null, null));                   // true 
console.log(deepEqual(null, {}));                     // false
console.log(deepEqual({a: 1}, {a: 1}));               // true
console.log(deepEqual({a: 1}, {a: 2}));               // false
console.log(deepEqual({a: 1}, {a: 1, b: 2}));          // false
console.log(deepEqual({a: {b: 2}}, {a: {b: 2}}));     // true
console.log(deepEqual({a: {b: 2}}, {a: {b: 3}}));     // false

Be careful with while(true). It works, but just make sure it has a good escape condition. And probably better to put then this condition into the while loop.

For exmaple: while(input !== "letmein")
